After passing an interim budget bill, PM Lecornu's approach faces scrutiny
subhead: Parliament urgently passed a stopgap 'special finance law' on Tuesday, ensuring the state doesn't shut down in the absence of a budget. Despite criticism of his approach, Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu remains convinced that a compromise is still possible.

Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babis gradually distances himself from support for Ukraine
subhead: Back at the helm of the Czech government since early December, populist Andrej Babis has sought to distance himself from the strongly pro-Kyiv stance of his predecessor, while stopping short of aligning with Russia. His defense minister, who has voiced clear support for Ukraine, was sharply reprimanded.

title: A 'two-headed' art market in 2025
subhead: In 2025, art market professionals observed a sharp divide between the sluggish mood of the first half of the year and the fireworks of the November sales in New York.

title: Ukraine loses Siversk, a bastion guarding the last quarter of the Donetsk region
subhead: The Russian invading army has completed its occupation of the city of 10,000 inhabitants, which had held out for three and a half years. The eastern flank of the last conurbation in the Donbas that is still under Ukrainian control now seems exposed.

title: From Trump Tower to Queens, in search of the perfect Christmas tree
subhead: 'My Christmas under Trump' (2/5). Journalist Georgia Husson settled in New York right in the middle of the holiday season preparations. Today, she wanders through the city in search of the perfect decorations for the (expensive) conifer.

Disneyland Paris at 40: When Mickey Mouse said 'bonjour' to Paris
subhead: On December 18, 1985, the Walt Disney Company approved the construction of its first European theme park in Marne-la-Vallée, about 30 kilometers east of Paris. The prime minister secured the deal after tough negotiations between envoys from the Socialist government and an American corporation seen as the embodiment of ruthless capitalism.

title: Is Paris finally embracing musical theater?
subhead: Long considered unpopular by the French, musicals have flourished recently in the capital. But is this just a mere trend to which the French will inevitably turn their noses up?

title: Giorgia Meloni: Neo-fascist or far right? Why Italian PM's tenure raises questions among political experts
subhead: The Italian prime minister has been in power now for three years. Italy's political experts question the normalization of this leader, who comes from a neo-fascist background. Has her tenure really been accompanied by a moderation of her political views?
